G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, placing this action within the subject‑matter jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County because the cause of action arose in Worcester, Massachusetts, and the Property is located in Worcester County.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..raw_text: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 931 N.E.2d 142 (2010)
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a property owner or person in control of real property owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the maintenance and safety of the premises, including protection against foreseeable hazards such as accumulations of snow and ice.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that Massachusetts premises liability law imposes on property owners a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors as to conditions on the premises, and specifically states that this same duty applies to hazards arising from snow and ice. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and confirms that accumulations of snow and ice are to be treated like any other foreseeable hazard on the property. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition about a duty of reasonable care including protection against foreseeable snow and ice hazards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708, 2.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful visitor and business invitee to the Property, a duty to use reasonable care to maintain the sidewalk, approaches, and access path in a reasonably safe condition in light of foreseeable risks of harm presented by winter weather, melt‑and‑refreeze cycles, and related snow and ice conditions.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708, 2.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a brief concurrence focused on rejecting rigid entrant classifications (trespasser/licensee/invitee) and does not discuss duties concerning maintenance of sidewalks or snow and ice conditions. While Mounsey generally is known for imposing a reasonable-care standard toward lawful visitors, the specific quoted text does not address winter weather, melt‑and‑refreeze cycles, or the scope of an occupier’s duty as framed in the proposition. On this limited text, the citation does not clearly support the detailed proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708, 2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322, 850 N..proposition: Defendant, as landlord and person in control of the Property’s common areas, also had a duty to maintain the common areas, including the sidewalk and entry path, in a reasonably safe condition for tenants and those lawfully on the premises at their invitation.
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322, 850 N..support_reasoning: The case expressly concerns a commercial lease where the tenant leased and controlled the entire building; it reaffirms that, in such circumstances, the tenant—not the landlord—has responsibility for keeping the premises safe, absent a contractual undertaking. While the opinion acknowledges a landlord’s potential duty regarding common areas under its control, it does so only in summarizing existing law and then finds no such common or appurtenant area here. The holding ultimately declines to impose a broader duty on the commercial landlord and thus does not support the specific proposition that this defendant, as landlord in control of common areas, had a duty to maintain sidewalks and entry paths in a reasonably safe condition.
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322, 850 N..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today leaves intact the rule that ‘a lessor of commercial premises is liable in tort for personal injuries only if either (1) he contracted to make repairs and made them negligently, or (2) the defect that caused the injury was in a “common area,” or other area appurtenant to the leased area, over which the lessor had some control.’ Chausse v. Coz, 405 Mass. 264, 266 (1989). … Gateway leased the entire building from the landlord, including the stairway where Humphrey’s accident occurred. It was Gateway’s responsibility to keep the leased premises safe…”}

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 402 N..proposition: Defendant, as landlord and person in control of the Property’s common areas, also had a duty to maintain the common areas, including the sidewalk and entry path, in a reasonably safe condition for tenants and those lawfully on the premises at their invitation.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 402 N..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that, under Massachusetts law, a landlord has a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common passageways under his control for the safety of tenants and their visitors, and it cites that rule as already established precedent (Lindsey and King). Although Young v. Garwacki itself extends the landlord’s duty into demised premises, its discussion of existing law squarely affirms that landlords who control common areas (such as entryways and similar appurtenances) owe a duty of reasonable care to tenants and lawful visitors. This aligns with the proposition that a landlord in control of common areas must maintain them in a reasonably safe condition.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 402 N..relevant_excerpt: In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that “the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.” Id. at 82. In King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, we extended the landlord’s general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways to include tenants as well as their visitors.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 292 N.E.2d 863 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner or possessor of land may be liable for injuries resulting from an unsafe condition on the premises where the owner knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the condition and unreasonably failed to correct or warn of it.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the general duty of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe for patrons or to warn them of dangers that are not likely to be known to them and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. That is essentially the same as the proposition: liability may arise when the possessor knows or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should know of an unsafe condition and unreasonably fails to correct or warn. Although the plaintiff ultimately loses on the time-notice issue, the opinion clearly affirms the stated duty rule.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: "The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know."

Falco v. James A. Fulford, Inc., 354 Mas.raw_text: Falco v. James A. Fulford, Inc., 354 Mass. 299, 237 N.E.2d 33 (1968)
Falco v. James A. Fulford, Inc., 354 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner or possessor of land may be liable for injuries resulting from an unsafe condition on the premises where the owner knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the condition and unreasonably failed to correct or warn of it.
Falco v. James A. Fulford, Inc., 354 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns marketable title and the validity of a municipal taking affecting a purchase-and-sale agreement for land. It does not address premises liability, duties of landowners to entrants, unsafe conditions, or failure to warn or repair. Therefore it provides no authority for the stated Massachusetts landowner liability proposition.
Falco v. James A. Fulford, Inc., 354 Mas.relevant_excerpt: It follows that the Congregation could not convey the marketable title to the described estate which the agreement called for. Jeffries v. Jeffries, 117 Mass. 184, 187. O'Meara v. Gleason, 246 Mass. 136, 138. The agreement provides that if the Congregation is “unable to give title or to make conveyance as above stipulated, any payments made under this agreement shall be refunded, and all other obligations of either party hereunto shall cease.”

Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661, 63 N.proposition: Even if Defendant did not have actual notice at the earliest stages, Defendant had constructive notice of the hazardous condition because the melt‑and‑refreeze cycle and resulting ice accumulated over a period of several days under predictable February weather conditions in Worcester; a reasonably prudent property owner exercising due care would have discovered and remedied the icy condition.
Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661, 63 N.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address premises liability, snow and ice, constructive notice, or any melt‑and‑refreeze accumulation over time. It concerns an employee’s fall from a roof and whether the employer’s failure to provide staging, in violation of a safety rule, was a causally related act of negligence. Nothing in the holding or reasoning discusses notice of hazardous conditions or the standard of care for icy accumulations, so it cannot be cited as authority for the stated proposition.
Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661, 63 N.relevant_excerpt: "To recover, the plaintiff was required to prove negligence on the part of the defendant that contributed to cause the death of her intestate. The plaintiff urges that this requirement has been met because the failure of the defendant to set up any staging on the roof where the intestate was working constituted a violation of Rule 6... The evidence would not warrant a finding that the violation of Rule 6, if there was one, bore any causal relation to the death of the intestate. What caused his fall is a matter of conjecture."

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 987.raw_text: Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 987 N.E.2d 1187 (2013)
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 987.proposition: Defendant’s duty encompassed taking reasonable steps—such as monitoring the condition of the path, responding to complaints, applying salt or sand, scraping or chopping away ice, or warning or redirecting pedestrians—to protect lawful visitors from the known and foreseeable risk of slipping and falling on ice.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 987.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize a landowner’s duty to "remedy" open and obvious dangers when the owner can and should anticipate harm despite the obviousness, but it does so in the context of a trampoline–pool setup, not icy walkways. The specific steps listed in the proposition—monitoring a path, responding to complaints, salting/sanding, scraping or chopping away ice, warning or redirecting pedestrians—are not discussed in this case, which instead concerns negligent design/maintenance of recreational equipment. The ice-and-snow, path-maintenance duties come from Papadopoulos and related cases, not from Dos Santos itself.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 987.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Ass'n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 338 (2010) (Soederberg), quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts, supra at § 343A comment f. … [T]he existence of an open and obvious danger will not necessarily relieve a landowner of the duty to remedy that danger.”}

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff in a negligence action must prove duty, breach, causation, and damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim under Massachusetts law: duty, breach, causation, and damages. This is stated as a general rule, with a citation to a tort treatise, and is not limited to the specific firearm-storage facts, so it directly supports the claimed proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.raw_text: Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50, 525 N.E.2d 1305 (1988)
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: To the extent Defendant alleges comparative negligence, Plaintiff denies any negligence on her part; however, if Plaintiff is found to have been negligent, such negligence was less than that of Defendant, and Plaintiff’s claims are preserved under G.L. c. 231, § 85.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely explains that under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it exceeds the combined negligence of the defendants, and that otherwise recovery is merely diminished proportionally. The court explicitly contrasts this negligence framework under G.L. c. 231, § 85 with the absolute bar that applies in warranty via the Correia unreasonable‑use doctrine, making clear that negligence claims are preserved so long as the plaintiff’s fault is not greater than the defendants’ total fault.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85, Defendant’s liability in negligence is determined under principles of comparative negligence, and Plaintiff’s recovery is not barred so long as her negligence, if any, is not greater than the negligence of Defendant.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60H.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60H, Plaintiff seeks full and fair compensation for all elements of her damages recognized under Massachusetts tort law, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks prejudgment interest on any judgment in her favor at the rate provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B (for personal injury actions), from the date of commencement of this action.

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Plaintiff further seeks taxable costs as allowed by law under G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Rule 38 of the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure and G.L. c. 231, § 60, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
